message.content: {"facts":["A virtual machine (VM) is a software-defined computer that emulates a physical computer, including virtual CPU, RAM, storage, and network interfaces, running independently within a host system.[1][2][3][4]","VMs operate on a physical host machine using a hypervisor, which manages and allocates hardware resources like CPU, memory, storage, and networking to each VM.[1][2][4]","Each VM has its own operating system and applications, isolated from other VMs and the host, enabling multiple OS types to run concurrently on a single physical machine.[2][3][4]","Key virtual hardware components include virtual CPUs (vCPUs), virtual RAM, virtual hard disks (e.g., .vmdk, .vdi files), virtual network interface cards (vNICs), and optionally virtual GPUs and USB controllers.[1]","Virtualization technology allows a single physical server to host multiple VMs, improving hardware utilization and flexibility.[2][4]","VMs provide isolation, ensuring that processes and failures in one VM do not affect others, enhancing security and stability.[5]","Multi-tenancy is a core feature allowing multiple users or applications to share the same physical hardware securely via VMs.[5]","VMs are portable and can be transferred between different hardware platforms or cloud environments, facilitating scalability and disaster recovery.[5]","Virtual machines are widely used for software development and testing, running legacy applications, server consolidation, cloud computing, and enabling remote desktop environments.[1][3][4]","VMs enable running different operating systems on the same physical hardware, such as running Linux or MacOS on a Windows host.[2][3]","The global virtual machine market size was USD 11.11 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow to USD 12.73 billion in 2025, with a CAGR of 14.71% expected through 2034.[4]","Integration of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies into VMs is increasing, with the global AI market projected to reach USD 826.70 billion by 2030, influencing VM capabilities.[4]","VMs support various network configurations including bridged, NAT, and host-only modes to connect to the internet or local networks.[1]","Shared folders and virtual USB controllers allow VMs to interact with host files and physical devices, enhancing usability in development and testing.[1]","VM technology includes virtual servers, virtual server instances (VSIs), and virtual private servers (VPSs), which are common in cloud infrastructure.[4]"],"statistics":[{"value":"USD 11.11 billion","context":"Global is a fully functional software computer running on a physical host, isolated and independent from other VMs and the host OS.","Hypervisors are critical software that allocate physical resources to VMs multi-tenancy features make VMs secure and efficient for shared environments like cloud computing.","VMs are portable and scalable, supporting easy migration and disaster recovery across different hardware and cloud platforms.","Virtual machines are foundational to cloud infrastructure, enabling virtual servers and private servers.","The VM market is growing rapidly, driven by cloud adoption
